div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

p.hi: THE SUGGESTED NEW TRIPLE
ALLIANCE The Standard," commenting on the articles in the "Gre zhoto" and the "Vuosirche Zeit ong," remarks: 0.e of the writers unfold the opinion that if Great Britain, Germany,

d Anstria wera noited they would be strong enough to wird ff any dangar that threatere the msintenance of pe.. That i qite probable. What dong the writer mean by the three States being united"? As he refers to the strength of he combined Armies and Navies he seems to be suggesting an allia .ceThe condition of a healthy alliance are that its stipulations cover action on the part of each of the Powers parties to it identical with the action which that Puwar is bound to take in pursuance of its own ideals or vital interests. Two Powers whose independence or other great aims are threatened at the sme time by the game Power are naturally driven to combine for their mutual protection. This was the case in the time of Queen Elizabeth when the Baglish and Datch both found themselvea in conflict with the then formidable strength of Spain. It was the case in the time of William the Third, when Great Britain and Hollard were both defanding themselves against the aggressive policy of Louis XIV. The basis of un alliance is usually a common danger. Sometimes it has been a common parpose of expansion. Thas in 1865 the policy of Prussia was to establish herself at the head of a German confederation in the place of Austris. The parpose of Italy was to obtain possession of Venetis, then an Austrian province. Both Prussia and Italy were coatemplating the parsuance of their policy by force of arms, and therefore it was natural that they made an alliance. But it was not a very healthy alliance, because when Ita'y wished to begin the wat Prussia declared that though th3 alliance bound Italy to fight whenever Prussis should begin, it did not bind Prossia to begin when Italy was ready. This was possibly a correst interpretation of the letter of the treaty. Bat the Prussian interpretation greatly incensed the Italian statesmen, who never forgot the
treatment they receive on that occasior, though tbeir policy was saved by the Prussian victorier, in spite of the Italian defeat at Castozza.
The German writer hardly explaing the con. ditions of the new Triple Alliance at which he hinto. It could not be similar to the Pro880Italian Alliance of 1866, because Great Britain has no expansive purpose. She covets no territory, but merely wishes to maintain such rights and opportunities as sbo POSHOBH88. An alliance 'for aggressive purposes cannot be mennt, because Great Britain will not be a party to it. Tbe parpone must therefore be assumed to be defonrive. Bat it is not olear what is the danger to bo gaarded against. Great Britain is on very good terms with most of the Great Powers. She has no conflict of policy with the United Statee. She can bave done with Italy. With Pranco sbe has made up such small differences as existed and is on terms of more than usual intimacy. From Rassia she has in the visible fatore nothing to apprehend. Nor is it clear wbat dangør threatens Germany. Russis is not likely to be aggressive for years to come, and Rassis is always described by German statesmen as Germany's close friend. France certainly bas no intention of attacking Germany, and if she had Germany is able to protect herself. Moreover, the idea of inviting Great Britain to enter into an alliance to protect herself against Prance is a little absurd at the moment when Great Britain and France are in close upderstanding with one another. The writer in the "Vossische Zeitung" seems to have no very clear conception of what he wants. He is going back to the idea expressed by Bismarok fifty years ago, that a combination of Prussia, Aastris, and Great Britain would be a sure defence for each of the three. Bat after 1870 Bismarck let that iden drop and spent the rest of his official life in administering snabs to Great Britain and in coltivating by his owa speeches and all oth or availablo means the sentiment towards Bagland which in Bagland were not felt to be affectionate. If the writer in the Vossische Zeitung" wishes to persuade his country. men that this part of Bismarok's activity did not constitate his title to greatness and had better bo abandoned and forgotten be commands our sympathy and gratitade. Bat. he would be more likely to produca that desirable result if he were a little more explicit. The writer in another Garman paper approaches from a different point of view the relations between the two countries. He is loncerned about the projected railway to the Persian Gulf. The line has been carried through Asia Minor, and tbere are three great sections of it yet to be built. The first will carry it through the mountain ranges that
eparate the oplands of Asia Minor from the plain of the Upper Baphrates; tha second will take it across the plain to Bagdad; the third from Bagdad to the Persian Gulf. Tha German idea is that the railway should be built by German, French, and British capital, bat should be under German control and become an instrament for tbe establishment of German influence . from the Sea of Marmora to the Persian Galf. No intelligible reason has been given why " British capitalists should make themselyes the instraments of this extension of German inAlence, least of all wby the British Government, which had hitherto been the only Power exercising any importantinfidence in the Persian Galf should make way for another influence in that region. The German writer suggests that the British Government should approach the German Government on the subject. Why? The only view which a British Government can express, unless it wishes to find itaelt at variance with its own people, is that the section of the line between the Persian Gulf and Bagdad should be under a British control analogous to the German control of the Asia Minor section. If the German Goverament wishes for British partisipation in the enterprise it will make no difficulty on that score, and if the German Government makes diffi. coltios in this matter th) only reason can be that it wishes to insist on German as distinct from British control to the Persian Galt terminus.

p.hi: Sulolde.
A native of Chibin el Km employed at Esbet Parkeh committed suicide by hanging himself on Sanday. Quatorzo Juillet
The French fåte of July 14 will not be held at Ghozireh, as proposed, but in the Esbekieh Gardens, Cairo. School Examination
The examination of the elementary schools opened yesterday morning at the Ministry of Publio Instruction, Cairo. Alhambra Theatre.

div.p: The Geisha is again billed for prodaotion at the Alhambra this evening. It is the piece which has met with the most sQ00888 during the present operetta season. Murder at Tahta.

p.hi: News comes from Tahta that a native of Kom Badr, Tahta Markaz, while oarrying fuel to a lime kiln in that village a few days ago, reoeived a shot and fell dead on the spot. Three nativos, who were seen near the kiln at the time, have been arrested on suspicion.
Alexandria Bonting Aooldent.

The funeral of M. Maurise Mizrahi, one of the viotims of the boating accident which occurred in Alexandria barbour last Friday night, will take place at 5 p m. today from the Jewish Hospital in Moharrem Bey, where his body, on being recovered yesterday, was removed. Schooner Refloated.

The Tarkish schooner which capsized on coming into Alexandria harbour last week, was refloated this morning by means of the big derrick belonging to the Ports and Lighthouses Administration. She was towed to a point near Ras-el Tin, where a fire-engine is er geged in pamping the water out of the vessel. Cairo Museum

Every Wednesday until further notice the Rev. J. Hardy, Chaplain to the Forces, will show round the Museum at Kasr el-Nil any military people who will meet him at the gate at 9.30a.m. Oa Wednesday, 20th inst., the General Offioar Commanding has most kindly offered to point out a few of the most interesting things.
Revue d'Egypte.

The May issue of the "Revue d'Egypte et d'Orient," which we have jast reosived, is an exceptionally interesting number, and contains contributions by Mossrs. Lonis Fleri, Henri Thuile, Jehan d'Ivrsy, Marian de Dowbor, Maroel Collière, Jacques Rys, Leon Danbel, Louie Pergaud, Jean Bach Sisley, and Henry Devris; an appreciation of the Resny Brothers and M. Fleri's "Cooflit Taroo-Bgyptien" being perhaps the best. Of the short stories, "L'Héritière" has considerable merit. Istituto Savola.

At the exhibition of work executed by the pupils of the Istituto Savoia in Rosetta street, quite the most remarkable exhibits are those of Miss Adela Scherater, who has on view some exquisita oil paintings, notably one of the Mahmoudieh Canal, which 'elicited the special admiration of the Italian Consul on his visit to the sohool. The work reflects the greatest credit on the young artist, as well as on het teacher, Sig. Fasols, under whose tuition we understaud she has only been for one year. Charity Conoert

In aid of the widow and children of the late Sergt. Major Smith, R.E., a concert was given on Saturday evening last in the grand ball of the Continental Hotel. The committee snlisted the sympathies of practically all the musical talent now in Cairo, and the concert was an unqualified su00e88 in point of merit and financial results. The string band of the Ist Lancashire Fasiliers was in attendance, and gave a number of excellent selections. Mrs. Nolan, Miss Schall, Captain Tuoker, R.E, Mr. Ww. Hayes, and Lee.-Corporal Newton partionlarly distinguished themselves, ard we are glad to know that a very sabstantial sum has been realised by the energetic committee on behalt of a most worthy oause.

FEARED RENEWAL OF TROUBLES.

p.hi: ST. PETERSHURG, June 18. Five soldiers and policemen were wounded and two killed at Warsaw on Saturday A police officer, his wife, and two soldiers were shot dead on Sur day. No arrests have been made.
(Renter)

div.p: London, June 18. The leading Jewish members of the Doms have telegraphed to Mr. Lucien Wolf stating that the events at Bielostok are clearly the beginning of an organised massacre, which only the most energetio intervention can prevent. They beg that an appeal be made to all influences to help them.

p.hi: (Reuter) ST. PETERSBURG, June 18. There is an increase in the agitation amongst the sailors and workmen and the troops at Kronstadt. A repetition of the October disturb ances is feared. Reinforcements and guns have arrived.
(Reuter) Sr. PETERSBURG, Jane 18. The Dama has unanimously adopted the creation of an Agrarian Commission. (Havas)
WARSAW, Jane 18. - Anti-Senite troubles have broken out in the Grodno government.
(Banca)

div.p: NEGOTIATIONS PROGRESSING.

p.hi: LONDON, June 18. The 'Standard" learns that the Anglo Russian nerotiations with a view to a general under standing are progressing satisfactorily. In order to allay suspicions, Germany has been assured that no agreement will be signed affecting ber interests, especially in the region of the Bag+ dad Railway, and that no attempt will be made to impose international control. (Router
SOUTH AFRICA.
LIBERALS AND CHINESE LABOUR.
LONDON, June 18. A section of the Liberal Press persists in the demand for the stoppage of the importation of Chinese to the Rand and the speedy deporta tion of those already there.
The "Daily News" declares that the relno tance of the Government's agents to execute Site policy is making it the langhing-stook of South Afrioa.
The Tribane" continues its campaign against the continuance of Lord Selborno in office.
HOUSE OF COMMONS.
SUMMER RECESS.

LONDON, Jane 18. HOUSE OF COMMONS.-Sir H. CampbellBannerman stated that the Government proposed to adjourn during Aagast and September and to re-assemble in the Autumn. He moved the closure resolation mentioned on the 15th inst. Mr. Balfour's amendment was rejected by 341 votes to 171. (Router)
THE DREYFUS AFFAIR.
BEFORE COURT OF CASSATION.

PARIS, June 18. At a public sitting of the Court of Cassetion, a representative of the Pablis Prosecutor reviewed the case, maintaining that no treason bad been committed by Dreyfas or anyone else, but that the whole affair of mystification was the outcon e of coincidences and hasty conolusions, arrived at as a result of the operations of agents-provocateurs and the counter-espionage department. He demanded the cancellation of the conviction without re
PARIS, June 18. Councillor Moras related the facts which necessitated the oase going into Cassation. Dreyfus was not present at the discussion.
trial.

CONGO FREE STATE.
SIR E. GREY'S FIRM ATTITUDE.

p.hi: LONDON, June 18. The correspondence in connection with the Congo Free State, just pablished, shown that Sir E. Grey repeatedly demanded, and the Congo Government persistently refused, the poblication of the evidence of the Boquiry Commission. The Government maintained that no Power had any right to interfere on behalf of the natives, but Sir E. Grey affirmed the fall right of the Powers to secure the observance of the treaty obligation.
NAVAL MANEUVRES.
BATTLESHIPS COLLIDE.
London, Jane 18. The Resolution collided with the Ramillies during the mancuvres. The latter has been towed to Chatham with a damaged propeller.
KAISER AND PRINCE BULOW.
BERLIN, Jane 18. The Emperor paid a visit to Prince von Balow.

div.p: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
PROPRIETORS OF A DAILY.

p.hi: Ten members of the Legislative Council met H. B. Mustapha Pacha Pehny on Sunday to explain their scheme of publishing & daily vernacular paper. The Prime Minister agreed to their scheme and its inventors thereupon issued invitations to a large number of notables to attend & meeting that will be held on Saturday next at the house of Mahmoud Pachs Saleiman at Cairo. A subscription will then be opened to bring up the capital of the new journal to L.E. 15,000 in 1,500 ehares which will not be negotiable.

THE SUDAN No further news is reported from Kordofan. Heavy rains ale reported from Goz Abou Goma land Sings, and the natives believe that this year's rain in these districts will reash a record figure.
THE PLAGUE.

The weekly plagae balletin issued by the Public Health Department shows that during the week ending the 17th inst. five cases of plagoe were notified in Egypt, three of which occurred at Alexandria, one at Port Said, and one at Tantah. Three cases anded fatally and there are still ten cases under treatment.
Since the 1st January 356 cases have been notified, as compared with 77 and 611 dering the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904 respectively.
FRENCH EDUCATION IN EGYPT.

An interesting ceremony took place in Cairo on Wednesday last week, when a reception was held at the French Club in honour of M. Marcel Charlot, delegated by the Government of the Repablie to inspect the French schools in Egypt. An enthasiastic speech by M. Toussaint Caneri, Depaté de la Nation, was responded to by the guest of the evening. who, after thanking his hosts for their reception, spoke of the effect of French education in Egypt and expressed a hope that French influence would continue to increase throughout the country.
A vin d'honneor followed the speeches and was attended by most of the principal members of the French colony now remaining in Cairo.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The S.S. Roman Prince, from Alexandria, arrived at Mancbester last Saturday.
The Moss liner Rameses sailed from Liverpool on Saturday afternoon and is dae bere about the 30th inst., with passengers, mails, and general cargo

NO TROOPS LEAVING EGYPT.
STATEMENT BY MR. HALDANE.
(Gazetto's Spoolal Sorvice).

p.hi: LONDON, Tuesday, Jane 19. In the House of Commons yesterday Mr. Haldane informed Mr. Asbley, in answer to a question, that no British troops had been ordered to leave Egypt. He added that the number of the troops forming the Army of Occupation was at present under consideration.
THE DENSHWAL AFFAIR.

The Government has decided to charter & stenmer from Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son which will proceed to Chibin al-Kom for the 096 of the jadges of the special Court daring the trial of the accused in the Denghwai outrage.

"Al Abram" publishe & telegram from Chibin el Kom to the effect that Ismail Bey Aasem hss volanteered to act as counsel for the defendants. Ibrahim Bey Helbawi bas left Cairo to represent the police. The secretary of the special Court is Osman Bey Mortada.
The procedare at the trial will be oral. Sentence will be delivered at the close of the proceedings and will be carried outimmediately.
The gan's taken from the British officers have been diso0 vared in the houses of oertain natives of Denshwai village.
Captain J.8 Bystock, R.A.M.C., and Lieut. 8. G. Smithwick, 1st Royal Dublin Fasiliers, who had been in Cairo in connection with the enquiry, have rejoined the Manted Infantry at Batanour

div.p: EGYPT'S TRADE.
MAY CUSTOMS RETURNS.

p.hi: The total value of the imports into Egypt daring last month amounted to L.E. 1,897,123, an increase of LE. 363,444 on last year's figures for May. Great Britain wa', as ugual, the chief importer, supplying Bgypt with L.B. 569,940 worth of goods, an increase of LE. 63,555 on 1905, while the British total import for the first five months of the year reached L.B. 2,852,294, against L.B. 2,653,062 daring the corresponding period last year. German imports show a large increase for the montb, as do Austrian and French figures, Germany, with L.E. 138,194 imports against LE, 69 811 in May 1905, and Austria, with L.B. 163,091 against L.B. 94,482, doing best. For the month France comes second among the importers to Great Britain and is followed by Tarkey, Austria, Germany, and Italy.

For the five months of the present year Great Britain is followed by France and Tarkey, France importing L.B. 1,034,172 worth of goods, against LB 876,285 in the first five months of 1905. Turkey, Austria, Belgiom, Germany, Italy, and British Eastern Possessions follow in the order named.

Bxports show A great increase for the month and the unfinished year. Goods worth LB. 1,349,663 were exported in May 1906, an increase of L E. 75,320 on the corresponding month last year; and the January 1.May 31 figures shown an increase of no less than LE 1,920,731. England was the best costomer in the five months, followed by Germany, France, and Rassia, in the order named, the last country taking a large quantity of cotton during May. more indeed than France or Germany. Up to date the value of the cotton export for 1906 has been very high, amounting to L E. 8,394,133, agaicst L.B. 6,097,900 in the early part of 1905, although the quantity remains much about the same. In the sugar and cereal exports & great falling-off is noticeable, while imported cereals show & 25% inaresse, sign of the times when the price of provisions is, showing 80 steady & tendency to rise and the cultivation of cereals and foodstuffs generally is decreasing pari passu with the increase of the ares onder cotton. The exporta of Sadanese origin-ivory, ostrich feathers, beeswax, eto.-bow a decided rise. The egg export has improved and the increased export of bedna to the Ottoman Empire is an amusing feature of the returns. In cigarettes there is a decrease of LE. 2.976 for the month bot an increase of LE. 17,158 for the whole 5 months period, Great Britain, Germany and, far behind, Austria were the chief porcbasers of Egyptian cigarettes. The amount of coin declared imported was only LE. 519,932, compared to L.E. 1.089.787 in May 1905. British sovereigos were most numerous, both in the import and export returns of coin.

div.p: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex
pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits troe discussion.

p.hi: GERMAN COMPETITION.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Sir,-la your Satarday's extract from the Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, re Egypt's imports, I note that Germany's share in the supply of locomotives
is L.B. 31,296 ont of a total of L.E. 36,924. 1 I should like very much to kaow the reason.

Were these orders given be ease the locomotives were of better make or cheaper price ? or are the German engines the most suited to Bgyptian railways in praference to British manufactares ? If you could fie this matter out, I should deem it a patriotic act. -Your, etc.
XENOS. Alexandria, Jane 18.

div.p: "EGYPTIAN TEMPLES.".
MR. OGILVIE'S EXHIBITION.

p.hi: Mr. Frederick F. Ogilvie is exhibiting at the "Modern Gallery," in Bond Street, London, a collection of 64 water colour and oil paintings of views in Egypt, a number of them being scenes in or about the ancient templen, sepe. cially of those at Deir el Babari. Oar London Correspondent has had an opportunity of inspeoting these works and is able to say how scourately they represent the Boonery of the Nile Valley. Mr. Ogilvie has been specially Anocessful in delineating the delicate tinte,and colourg, associated with the sunsets and gaprises in Egypt, especially in the smaller landscapes. In No. 4, "Camp of Bedawin," the peopliar greenish hoe of the sky from part of the western horizon op to the zenith, which for a few minutes is part of the celestial pageantry of many sunseta' in Egypt, is admirably portrayed. It was, as the late M. Groff showed, this green sky tint which canned the Egyptians to paint many of the inhabitants of the nether world that colour. In No. 62 the same sunset radiance is painted, and the sky's reflection in a narrow pool, a final remnant of the late Nile overflow, is beautifolly rendered, as is the deep sbade of blue of the distant hilly. No. 63. "Near Wasta," also gives the raddy golden hue apon temple top, and hill sommit, such 88 every visitor to Egypt remembers with delight.

No. 17, a larger canvas than usual, of "Harvest time in Upper Egypt," shows the great distance of a landscape in the clear Egyptian air. Another noticeable picture is that of the "Small Temple at Medinet Habu," where not only are the remains of that edifice rendered into an exquisite picture, but the cloud tints are perfectly rendered.

A picture entitled "Near Sobag" gives an excellent idea of Egyptian scenery, as does one of "Sunrise on the Nile" wherein the river mist of early morning partly concealing the dahabeabs, and the heights which border the valley showing above the baze, recall many a memory to those who have lived in Egypt. Many paint. inga are of soene in Cairo and are interesting to the lover of Arabio architecture, such as the scene in a courtyard with a fine old mushrabia baloony upon one side. Io this, too, the intensity of Caireno sunlight is faithfully shown.

An important item of the exhibition is the series of painting of tbe newly discovered Shrine of Hathor from Deir el Bahari. We have piotares of the goddess herself, and of ber arohed canopy shrine, and of the recess in the bill in which the whole was found. These are likely to prove « grest attraction to Mr. Ogilvie's exbibition, and we hope, now that in London there must be many thousands of psople to whom Egypt is familiar, that his piotares, which are the result of many years! residence in the country, will meet with the appreciation they deserve.

div.p: :. CHRISTIANITY AND ISLAM.
THE POSSIBILITY OF UNION.

p.hi: Professor Ramsay delivered the Rede Lecture at Cambridge last week, taking as bis subject "The wars between Moslem and Christian for the possession of Asia Minor." He said the war which bagan with the invasion of Crigia by the Mohamedan Arabs in A.D. 641 ended, in & certain sense, in the definitive conquest of Cilicia by Saltan Selim about 1516. It formed only an episode in that great spic of bistory, the never-ending atraggle between East and West, between Asiatic and Boropean, and the best hope for the fatore of the world was that the struggle should be made into a balance and harmony of diverse elements. Dealing with the history of the oor flict, and sketching the "might have beens," the 'estarer said that as war became more and more the business of the true believer in Islam, thonght, edacation, religion, society, and family lifeall deteriorated. Especially conspicucas was the one fatal error of Islam-the low estimation of woman, which was probably dae in great part to the reaction against the cult of the mother of God" which the Christians had restored to their worship daring the fifth century. The intellectual and spiritual standing among women was depreciated, and the inevitable result was the destraction of all that training of the young in ideals in the home by the mother which slone could make a progressive people, and which was so painfally lacking in the land of the Tark.
In happier circamstances, more favparable to development, Islam might have continued

to be, as it was at first, a parar and higher I faith than the debased and paganised Christian Church. It contained within itself mach of the essential thought of Christianity, and the fundamental dogma that Jesus was divine, where88 Mohamed was hamad, possessed great potantiality. Evaryone who had lived in Tarkey could attest the easiness of relations between the Christian and Mohamedan religions. The inference was inevitable, and he ventored to re-quote his own words, "I believe the Tarks, as soldiers, and the Greeks, as traders, will, united, make a happier country than eitber race ovald by itself." The conciliation was easy and followed at once natarally wberever there was fair and orderly administration. Reviewing the dissensions among Christiane in the Bust, Protessor Ramsay said the Moslem conquest was made possib'e only by Osmoli skill in playing of Christian against Christian.

Christianity, ha concluded, could conquer only by anion against the foods of barbarism which were always and everywhere threatening to engalf and drown oat civilization in the world, and union was never possible unless the seata of Christians learnt to respect each other's opinions.

p.hi: H.E. Mustapha Pacha Pebmy arriver at Alexandria tomorrow from Cairo. The Prime Minister will spend abont three weeks at San Stefano Casino, and will leave for Barope on the 7th prox.
H.E. Pakhry Pacha arrives here this after. noon from Cairo. After spending a week bere the Minister will proceed to Port Said and will leave by the P. & 0. steamer for England.
Lord and Lady Cromer left Cairo at 11 a.m. to-day for Port Said, where they will embark on the P. &0. 8.8. China for Europe
Sir Maloolm Macllwraith leaves for England to-day
Sir William Garstin has left tot Barope.
H.E. Saba Pacha, Postmaster-General, retarned to Alexandria yesterday from Earope.
M. Wanderlich, the new German Consol at Alexandria, is expected to arrive to-day from Marseilles.
Mr. Hellwig, late German Consal here, leaves on Wednesday for his new post at Marseilles.
Mme Harari Pacha left for Europe on Satar. day by the 8.8. Habsburg.

We regret to announce the death of Mrs.. Ralph Peacock, wife of Mr. Ralph Pancook, the divisional loco saperintendent, Egyptian State Railways, Cairo, whioh occurred on Sunday at noon at the Descondages' Hospital. The faneral took place this morning at the British Cemetery, Old Cairo, and was largely attended by the many friends of Mr. Percook.
Doring the absence of Johnson Paoba, Mr. Marshall Hewat will act as controller of the Model Workshops in Cairo.
Mr. R. E. Monteith-Smitb, inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, will go on leave, on th: 23rd inst. and is dae back on the 22nd September.
The marriage of Miss Elena Fiorentino to Mr. Gialio Trapani di Montepagano will take place in the saloon of the Zizinia Theatre on the 23rd inst., at 6 p.m.

div.p: LES PROCES EN PREEMPTION

p.hi: La Cour d'appel mixto A ou à statuer der nièrement sur diverses demandes on préemptio. qui ont été rejetées pour la plupart.
C'est ainsi qu'à l'audience da 31 mai der nier, oing domandeurs en préemption ont és débontés pour des motifs divers.

Dans une aff'sire Moustapba Attia Mon. cbaratta contre Banjamin Agbion, il s'agissai d'une préemption exercée par un voisin contre un autre voisin acquéreur. L'arrêt décide à o propos en principe: "que si la loi admet la préemption du voisin même à l'égard du voi sin acquéreur, l'esprit de la loi et d'équité commandent, pourtant que, toutes choses étant à peu près égales au point de vue de la situation respective des fonds, l'acquéreur dili gent soit préféré au préemptuor qui a néglige de faire une acquisition soidisant utile, on fait, la présomption d'un intérêt supérieur; que préférer le préempteur reviendrait à encoura ger une spéoulation répréhensible, consistant à prendre une attitude d'expeotative avec une arrière pensée de préomption, au lieu d'offrir immédiatement au voisin on joste prix; qu'ainsi la jarispradenos admet qu'en l'égard de vuisin acquéreur, le voisin préempteur doit justifier d'un intérêt supérieur, qui soit parti nlièrement certain, évident, incontestable; et qu'il faut, on cas de doute, respecter la liberté des oontrata et débouter le demandeur en confor. mité de viel adage : actore non probante, reus absolvitur."
Ba conséquencer, la cour déboute le deman. deur "sur la base même des données d'une expertise " dont les conclusions étaient pour; tant favorables au préempteur.
Dans une antre oanse (J. M. Sapriel et fils contre El Cheik Abou Zeid et Consorts),- le préempteur est débouté pour n'avoir pas jus. tifié de sa prétendue qualité de propriétaire voisin.
Ba, l'espèce le préempteur invoquait des ventes a réméré.

La Cour décide que la teneur même des actes produits révélait de véritables nantissemonts auxquels on avait donné la forme falla cieuse d'une vente, dite à réméré, en roe d'élader la disposition de la loi, qui défend de stipuler que l'objet da gage restera, faute de paiement, la propriété de créar cier, qui a seulement le droit de provoquer la vente sous les mêmes conditions que tout autre créancier" (C.C. art. 665).

Enfin dans deux autres affaires, se présentait, comme dans l'affaire de Mera House, la question de savoir si la contiguité légale des deux fonds existait dans l'espèce, étant a priori soquis au procès que les deax fonds ne sont contigos que d'un seul oôté et la contro verse portant eur la point de savoir si las fonds, litigieux doivent être tenus pour ruraux ou arbains.

Catte question était soulevée poar la première fois en appel. Dans l'ane des affaires (Alfred Campos contre Hassan Aly Seif), il s'agissait d'an terrain vague situé sur le territoire da village de Siouf; et dans l'autre af faire, (Khalil pacha Kayat contre Hanna Dichkekinian), d'an terrain planté de dattiers et situé à Zsbrieb.
Dans les deux causes, les terrains ont été considérés comme ruraut et conséquemment la préemption a été écartés,

La Cour reprenant la thèse déjà développée, dans l'arrêt de Mens House, décide " que la * patare urbaine og rarale d'an fond dépend " selon la lettre et l'esprit, de la loi sur la pré"emption, da point de savoir si le fond est " situé en dedans ou en dehors d'ane agglomé. * ration batie ; qu'il est en effet aisé de com#prendre que la préemption doive être plus " facilement admise dans la première hypo"thèse, à raison des incommodités spéciales « que les rapports de voisivage peuvent offrir " et des limitations à l'exercice da droit de " propriété que peut entrainer la proximité " des constructions édifiées ou à édifier dans * les centras dits urbains."

Dans les deux causes, les préempteurs se prévalaiant du bat spéonlatif que les préemptés avaient erén vue en achetant le terrain préempté à un prix indiquant une intention de transformer l'immeuble en terrain à bâtir. Mais la Cour déclare cette raison non cɔnolaante, "oar la loi (dit-elle), en "parlant de terrains destinés à être bâtis," vise expreguément une destination réelle, objective et actuelle, résul tant de leur sitaation dans une ville ou on village et non pas une destination parement subjective et partant plus ou moins hypothé tique on aléatoire."

A signaler encore un arrêt renda en cause de Alfred Nahman - contre Nesler et Cie sur une importante question de forme : l'arrêt de oide, par confirmation d'on jugement du Tri bunal Mixte d'Alexandrie, que la demande en préemption ne peut être valablement introduite que par exploit notifié à personne on au domioile réel de l'assigné; l'art. 15 da Décret sur la préamption, qui règle la forme de la demande en préemption, n'ayant consacré en la matière aucune dérogation à la règle générale de la signifioation à personne ou aa domicile réel. Dans l'espèce le préempteur s'était cro antyrisé'à notifier l'exploit au domicile elu par l'acquéreur dans une mise en demeure que ce dernier notifie au voisin en conformité de l'art. 19 da Déoret anr la préemption.

p.hi: Le Caire, Lundi 18 Juin. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a été réduit, vendredi passé, de 1/8 A 3/8 pour cont. p.

div.p: Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a clôturé le même jonr, en baisse de 1/4 de livre I v á 88 3/4 et samedi en nouvelle baisse de 1/8 à 88 5/8. Par contre, l'Unitée « hauré, en ce deux séance, de 1/4 A 104 1/2. La National Bank, l'Agricole et la Daïra sont restées ir variées à 25 1/3, 93/8 et 17 1/8. La Delta Light a recolé de 1/4 & 11 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier a perda 2 V franos vendredi passé pour les regagner la lendemain £ 770. La Banque d'A hènes a ne trogradé de 1 frano a 154.

p.hi: Ioi, nous avons eu, co matin, un marché calme, avec des transactions restreintes et des obangements peu importante dans les coure.

La National Bank et l'Agricole ont olótaré à leurs prix précédents, soit 25 1/29/16 et 9 5/8-11/16, La Banque d'Orient a reperda % franos & 130. Le Comptoir Financier a avancé à 7/8 l'action ancienne et 5 13/16 la nouvelle ; la part de fondateur est remontée à 38.

div.p: L'action Crédit Foncier s'est maintenue 770; la part de fondatear a reculé à 930 930. V

p.hi: La Béhéra a progressé à 36 1/2-37.
L'action Immobilière s'est inscrite à 368-370, ex coupon de 19 franos la part de fondateur à 568, ex coupon de 16 france.
Les actions privilégiées Tramways d'Alex andrie se sont relevées à 188 et les dividendes à 345.
Les Omnibus du Caire ont faibli à 24.
La part de fondatear Allotment a fléchi à 124-125.
Rien de particulier à signaler sur les autres titres.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nangovich se sont raffermis à 15 3/8-7/16 l'action ancienne et 5 5/16 3/8 la nouvelle. Les Baehler ont été également bien tenus à 5 1/4:5/16. Les Upper Egypt se sont consolidéz à 41/4. Les Splendid ont reculé à 3 7/8. .
Les Saoreries ont baissé à 21-22 francs.

Suivant les dernières informations de Paris, il se confirmerait que le Crédit Foncier Egyptien appellera sous peu le versement de Prs. 125 sur les actions, probablement en deux! paiements de Frs. 62,50.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Londres, en date da 10 Jain, les lignes suivantes :

La situation monétaire reste plus ou moins inohangée. L'escompte libre tend à se détendre légèrement ioi, bien que les prévisions ne soient pas favorables. L'état de la Barque d'Angleterre s'est, certes, amélioré ; la réserve de bil. lets est de plas de 43% et l'encaisse a reça da l'or poor acbats sur place et par arrivages d'Egypte. Mais les taux libres d'escompte trimestre et semestre sont nivelés « 1/16 pour cent près, ce qui indique bien l'opinion dominante sur le marché, .

A Berlin, cù le taux s'est quelque peu tenda, on est dans les mêmes idées. A Paris seulement, l'aisance persiste. A New York, one commission parlementaise & approuvé le projet de loi Fowler, qui crée un système de cironlaire monétaire appelé à empêcher les paniques d'antomne en permettant de satisfaire aux besoins de capitaux à l'époque des récoltes."
SHIPPING MOVEMENTS.
ALEX ANDRIA HARBOUR.

div.p: THE BAGDAD RAILWAY.
POLITICAL ASPECTS OF THE
UNDERTAKING
In a special article dealing with the Bagdadlo Railway, the "Grenzbote" (Berlin) expresses the opinion that the time has arrived for the

p.hi: British Government to enter into negotiation's Dwith Germany regarding the political aspects

div.p: of the undertaking. It observes that British 1 onpitalists are eager to partioipate in the enterprise, but that the German concession Airey will not consent to their co-operation except on conditions agreeable to the German Government.

p.hi: Two projects are at present under consider stion for the prolongation of the railway over the Tanrus Mountainp, at the foot of which the enterprise now res's. One of these prrjects favours the adoption of a north easterly ronto, the other ofa south easterly ronte. Each direction would perve different interests. Onca the moun tains have been crossed th) work of carrying the railway across the Mesopotamian Plain, says! the Gretz oto" will be comparatively easy and I rapid, and when Bagdad is reached the ques tion of a terminus on the Persian Gulf will immediately become aoute. The interests of R188in and Great Britain in that question, the journal insinuntes, are not identical but antagonistio. Moreover, the Rossian Govern ment for i6 part bas given the most explicit ASSOranoes to the Foreign Offio in Berlin that it will enter into no agreement with Great Britain affeoting German interests without first consalting with Germany or inviting its 00 operation. Sir Edward Grey has aleo repa- ! dinted the assumption that his Government desires to effect an understanding with Russia which shall be direoted against Germany

This being the case, the Grenabote" argues that it would be wiser if the British Govern! ment were to open a discussion with Berlin now instead of waiting until the railway has crossed the Tanrus, when time might be wanting to arrive at a settlement satisfactory to both countries. Great Britain, it adds, is notnated by the wish that the railway shall have its terminus at Koweit, and it is eminent. ly desirable that an agreement shall be estab. lished beforehand on that point in order that it an early beginning may be made upon the i extensive harbour and other works which the operations of the railway would entail. The completion of those works, it argues, would occupy beveral years.

Other questions requiring regulation are i those arising out of the forwarding of goods and the administration of the Castoms and postal services. The organisation of a post along the railway is one to which Germany attaches especial importance, and it would be essential in the opinion of the "Grenzbote," which assuredly derives its views from official!
quarters, that the post office at the Persian - Galf terminus should be German.

The journal concludes by emphasising the interest which Great Britain must necessarily take in the railway owing to the portentous consequences whioh it will have in strengtben. ing the foroes of the Moslem and in sabling the Soltan to concentrate his troops with grest rapidity at the extremities of his Empire.
BRITISH RELATIONS WITH

GERMANY: The generally friendly attitude of the Earopean, and especially the British, Press on the oooasion of the Emperor William's visit to Vienna has given politicians at Berlin (a tele. gram says) an opportunity of once more bringing to the fore the question of AngloGerman relations, which it is obviously the ohjaot of Germany's present polioy to improve. The hearty reception accorded to the German Borgermasters in England and the cordial speeches of British Ministers bave oreated the best impression on people of all classes, and the Government is desirous of maintaining this feeling.

The "Vossische Zeitang," discussing the Emperor William's visit as bearing upon the question, arg988 that if three nations like Great Britain, Germany, and Austria, posse88ing as they do the greatest Navy and the grestest oombined Armies in the world, were united they could ward off any danger that threatened the maintenance of peace. The journal expresses the hope that a meeting will be arranged between King Edward and the Emperor, although it admits that the time for it has not yet arrived. The Vossische Zaitong," however, notes with satisfaction that the relations between Great Britain and Ger many are now being disonssed in a spirit quite different from that of a year ago.

SHIPPING IN THE LEVANT. The Consular report for the trade of the Cyclades in 1905 shows that Great Britain has maintaincd her position in the Levantine porte, the tonnage of British shipping during the year having amountel to no less than 15,090.000 tons. Austria Hungary comes next with 7,380,000 tops, hon Greece with 5,920,000 tone, Turkey with 4,278,000 tona, Italy with 3,844.000 tons, ar d Russia with 3,3 6,0 0 tons. The carrying trade of Great Britain appears thas to be more than twice as much as that of ary of the Great Powers looally inteTested, while of th 88 not locally interested it is a noteworthy fact that Germany, which his made such efforts lately to obtain barking bosiness in the Levant (and German banking, of course, means to a large extent the promotion of German indastrist enterprise), was only represented in 1905 by a shipping of 1.770,000

p.hi: The country may have voted for the onifying of elementary schools under the publio autho rity, for the removal of any grievance under which Nonconformists suppored themselves to bo soffering, and for reasonable independence on the part of the teachers; but it certainly did not vote for the extinotion of denomination al teaching as given hitherto. So much the Government show that they recogniza, by assigning an important place in their Bill to facilities for the denominatione. But something has bappened between the general election and the introduction of the Bill. Not only are the facilities entirely one-sided and inadequate, but on the broad question of whether denomi. national sobools shall survive at all the Govern mont bave clearly wavered. (Timer.") Mr. Seddon's Death ''a loss to Empire."

The British Empire has lost one of thé statesmen whom it oould least afford to spare ; England bas lost one of her mont devoted sons. The totally unexpected and pathetio death of Mr. Seddon will awaken the sincerest regrat in this country, for very few Colonial statesmen have snooeeded in getting hold of the British poblio as Mr. Seddon did; none, with the exception of Ceoil Rhodes, bas ever appealed 80 vividly to the imagination of the British demoorsoy. Richard Seddon, or "King Dick," as he was popularly called, was a man after the boart of the demooracy of Bngland. He was one of themselves, in a sense that Rhodes was not: he way the arobiteot-or, rather, the builder-of his own fortones. (*Telegraph.") Power of Falth and Energy.

It was said of Daniel Webster that he was a steam engine in trousers; but an American visitor reported that Mr. Boddon had ontdone Webster, and could only be described as a human dynamo. To this energy, wbich was both pbysioal and mental, he added a genial manner, which was the genuine expression of a warm heart. "We must take a kindly view of homannature," was one of his favourite sayings, and one of the secrets of bis power. He had three supporting taiths-faith in himself, faith in New Zealand, and faith in the British Em pire. Such a man, who had played 80 oonspiouous a part in publio life, deserves Imperial honour. (Chronicle.") South African Approclation.

His (Mr. Seddon's) Imperialism was sometimes a little aggressive in manner and a little loud in itterance, but wben other poli. ticians were vilifying their country as it it were a den of thieves his honesty was A wholesome corrective. ("Cape Times.") Horrors of the Congo.

The witnesses heard by the Commission of Inquiry were oranimons, and it was found that on, all hands nativebad been killed or mutilated for not having brought in a sufficient quantity of rubber. ("Journal des Débats.") King Alfonso as Reformer.

During the last few years there has been a new note of sincerity and zeal in Spanish politics, and the King may bestow the greatest blessings on his country if he gives free play to the hope and ambitions that were so long defeated by the corraption and make believe of the official parties. (Tribune.") English Sport not Repulsive

In may be that in the English aniversities, as well as among the English pation in general, too much importance is attached to sport and games. But the happy mediom is diffioult to find, and exaggerated sport has certainly mothing repulsive in it, like drinking and debauchery. ("Die Woche," Berlin.) John Bull's Indifference to Sclonce.

At Berlin and other Continental centres of geograpbical and learned attainment, British indiffereuce to the claims of se'ence has long been a by word. What know we, for instance, of the interior of Mongolis, or of the watershed whence those mighty rivers, the Yangtse, the Mekong, the Salweer, and the Brahmapootra issue? Hardly anything of a really intorming character from the standpoint of science, geographical, racial, politioal, or comx eroial - ("Globe.")
